text: If you leave the company, you usually have a pretty short window in which to exercise them.

elements.text: If you leave the company, you usually have a pretty short window in which to exercise them.

text: Did you try a few different strategies in those 100 emails? Long-form vs. super short? Focused on their gaps vs. your credentials? Friendly & empathetic vs. straight to the point? I’m no cold pitching expert, but I’ve found the most success in taking an email that at least got a response and iterating from there in smaller batches until I’ve stumbled into a new formula that seems to work better.

text: Congrats, Shatonia!  I’ve been asked to explain revenue impact of content marketing efforts quite a lot in recent interviews. Not sure how standard that is, but something to potentially prepare for. I hope it goes so well!

elements.text: Congrats, Shatonia!  I’ve been asked to explain revenue impact of content marketing efforts quite a lot in recent interviews. Not sure how standard that is, but something to potentially prepare for. I hope it goes so well!

text:
Yes, usually 90 days. In some cases, you can negotiate an extension. Companies won't routinely do that, but it's possible in certain circumstances. Some extensions can run for years. (And even if you get an extension, ISOs will convert to NQs for instance after a window — that's according to tax code; not per company discretion. That means different tax implications for you.)

Also worth noting: Typically, even if you stay at a company, you have a maximum of 10 years to exercise each set of options (10 years from when each set is issued). If the deadline passes and you don't exercise, then you lose those rights.

Of course, every contract can be written to different terms, so you wanna check anything you agree to (and get professional advice if you're not sure).

I'm not a tax expert or financial expert. I'm sharing my experience. Always get professional advice if you need. A bit of spending on such can save you lots.

text: Hello all you content people. I'm trying to build up more of my crypto writing - but i'm not sure If I should just focus the work on Medium, or build out my own URL/Website. Ive had a ton of people - (mostly women),  reach out to me asking for "easy to understand" web3/crypto content, so I'm trying to provide that. I'm thinking Medium may be easier to share and grow? Also - this is a passion project and i'm not looking to monetize these. I'm just trying to create a place that will be informative, funny and not so tech heavy. TIA!

text: Well, it sounds like you're in the right mindset of continuous improvement/trial and error! That's a win in and of itself. Just wanted to double-check you weren't sending 100 nearly identical pitches :slightly_smiling_face: So maybe it's the positioning side that needs tweaking, or knowing exactly who the right prospect is. Best of luck!

text:
No, when I first started out, though, and I had no idea what I was doing I was sending mass emails to 50+ emails at a time of the same exact email, no personalization or anything.

Those were dark times.

Part of it is consistency. I sent all those in a week, constantly working and grinding on cold emails. I think I would have more success if I did more consistent emails, but not as many at a time.

text:
Depending on what experience you want for your audience, you might consider pubbing on <https://mirror.xyz/>

Articles on mirror look like everything else, but the whole ecosystem is plugged directly into web3. So someone who reads stuff you've published there probably has a better chance of finding web3/crypto related stuff more naturally by being in the space.

And while you're not looking to monetize... I'd say there's no harm in creating the potential to do it within the web3 space, which is probably easier on Mirror vs Medium. Food for thought!

attachments.fallback: Mirror: Create and connect your world on web3
attachments.text: The essential web3 toolkit for sharing and funding anything. From writing about your latest idea, to building a home for the next big DAO.
attachments.title: Mirror: Create and connect your world on web3

text: Hey Dylan! What’s your LinkedIn? I tried to find it but wasn’t able to. If you want, I’d be happy to connect and take a look at your page and offer some feedback. I’m a freelance content writer, and that’s where I get the bulk of my new clients, mostly inbound. I’ve found a lot of success connecting with other writers and content managers, commenting on posts and being helpful wherever I can. Generally, building a solid network of other freelancers is a great way to gain access to more referrals, since a lot of us busy writers like to share other freelancers that may be a good fit for prospects who reach out when we don’t have bandwith to help ourselves. Just a few thoughts!

Just a few thoughts!

text:
Some people are better at doing that than others. Like I have a couple of mentors who’ve hit it multiple times.

Also depends on a variety of factors:

• When are you joining? What stage?
• How big is the total addressable market?
• How’s the business doing? There are certain signals to look for, depending on what kind of startup it is.
• Who’s the competition and how are they doing?
• Whether there are rounds before or after you join, how soon after and what the latest valuation is.
• If you tend to join very early stage, it can be harder to tell. But if you join a midstage or later startup, it’s not that hard. That’s why some people don’t join early stage — it’s easier to see how the business is faring later. Or they join early stage if the leadership team has previously exited well, because that gives you much better odds.
• What’s your strike price? If it’s super low, it can be easy to come out ahead.
• Can you sell on the secondary market soon after you join?
The business fundamentals matter. Like I joined a startup the was already profitable (though still early) and it was easy to tell that my shares were worth exercising. Likewise, I know a number of people in the startup world whose options were clearly worth a crapload when they joined their startups or not long after. That’s actually part of the recruiting pitch for some startups — join us before the next round and your equity will rise.

Plus, if shares are already in demand on the secondary market, that’s a giveaway.

You also get more visibility in some companies vs. others, depending on how they share financials or not. Depends on your level and role sometimes. Finance people tend to have the best visibility.

Note: It can make a big difference if you’ve previously been with a startup that’s been successful. Why: Those folks get recruited by better startups. Like I turned down several later-stage startups that were well on their way and I knew they’d make a crapload of money (and they have since). And it’s not like I’m a business wizard (I had zero business exposure before changing careers in 2013); the signs were very strong.

One of my mentors was actually bewildered by me, because he said I was turning down some of the best opportunities that had come around in years — he could tell. Unlike me, his career priority was to make money. He’s now 40ish and retired.
